info: Free-verse poems extracted from Poetry Foundation.org and split into small sub-poems of length 8ish

poems.poem:
He was led to be hanged.
 How
 to write this scene?
 
 Was it winter? Summer?
 
 From behind the fence
 across the street
 his mother watched. What should I call her?
poems.title: A Script
poems.author: Uladzimir Niakliaeu

poems.poem:
Let’s say, Antanina.
 And he is Maxim.
 Why Maxim, and not Basil or Yanak?
 
 The stones tucked themselves under his feet,
 two magpies stalked him,
 poplar to poplar.
poems.title: A Script
poems.author: Uladzimir Niakliaeu

poems.poem:
You’ve ever been hanged?
 Me, never yet.
 And that’s the problem. So are the magpies.
 Why should there be two, not one?
 
 The gutters silver
 with spring waters.
poems.title: A Script
poems.author: Uladzimir Niakliaeu

poems.poem:
So was it spring? Alright. By the courthouse,
 gray soldiers, lined up in a row.
 In the park — ladies. And ladies’ men.
 
 And where’s mother? “It’s best without her,”
 he thought.
 Do change her name.
 How’s then?
poems.title: A Script
poems.author: Uladzimir Niakliaeu

poems.poem:
A truck
 with sides already dropped — 
 above it — a noose.
 
 Above a noose — 
 a cloud.
poems.title: A Script
poems.author: Uladzimir Niakliaeu

poems.poem:
Who’s sitting at the wheel? His brother? Son?
 No, a son is pushing it. A brother then.
 And from behind the curtain in a palace next to the courthouse
 she watches. Marysya? Alright, Marysya.
 
 Those magpies. Soldiers. Water. Park.
 That cloud again.
 And glances from the crowd. “It’s him ...
poems.title: A Script
poems.author: Uladzimir Niakliaeu

poems.poem:
Not you ... Not me ... For that, thank God ... ”
 Bells ringing.
 Will he hear the bells?
 
 Behind Marysya stands the one who shares her bed.
 With blazing epaulets. And profile. And a hand
 around her waist.
 A river embraces
poems.title: A Script
poems.author: Uladzimir Niakliaeu

poems.poem:
the park. A river jammed with ice.
 
 Life blazes, rings.
 
 To sum it up, considering all mentioned:
 “He was led to be hanged.”
 Alone.
   Translated from the Belarusian
poems.title: A Script
poems.author: Uladzimir Niakliaeu

poems.poem:
The sky is bright with stars
 After a hot day
 The coolness of my body
 Leaving finger by toe in the heat of the spa
 Looking through the garden lights
 At tall houses around me
 I thought, No, just happy
 The night is bright with stars,
 She told me
 She no longer missed her parents
poems.title: The Sky
poems.author: Dan Taulapapa McMullin

poems.poem:
But you loved them, I said
 I did, said she, more than myself
 And now I’m free
 That was my friend Pipi
 Such a whore, I said to myself
 Like me, such a whore like me
 As I hear the roosters of Samoa
 In the laughing of coyotes
poems.title: The Sky
poems.author: Dan Taulapapa McMullin

poems.poem:
ke pwoahn Pohnpei
 I told him as we kissed
 is that a good thing?
 he asked
 hell yea
 I wanted to say
 replaced it with another kiss
 inhaling the mix of last night’s sakau en Pohnpei 
 seir en wai, sweat
 rain
poems.title: the smell
poems.author: Emelihter Kihleng

poems.poem:
intoxicating
 taking me home
 
 he left that smell behind
 it would barely linger by the time
 he reached his destination
 I was headed for it
 so the smell stayed
poems.title: the smell
poems.author: Emelihter Kihleng

poems.poem:
bittersweet and blue
 on my skin, in my hair
 I carried it with me there
 where it grew
 mixed with mangoes,
 coughs, handshakes, pigs,
 babies, and old people
poems.title: the smell
poems.author: Emelihter Kihleng

poems.poem:
I’m back
 it now reeks
 won’t wash away
 with the other smells
 get in my car
 it hits me
 pungent remnants of the mwaramwar
 he left behind.
poems.title: the smell
poems.author: Emelihter Kihleng

poems.poem:
My eyes turned to salt in looking back,
 my thoughts stood still in gestures,
 in the silence of what’s been done;
 I gathered the crumbs of another lunch
poems.title: Staying
poems.author: Pierluigi Cappello

poems.poem:
and shook them into the garden’s vitreous air
 where the sun’s just cracked and spilled.
 Here, even a flutter of blackbird beyond the hedge
 stands still, as my words stand still, like ships in bottles.
 Your language is mine but mine is not yours.
 At home, I could feel myself thinking
 while the television glowed in shadow
 and a film score spread like smoke in a saloon.
poems.title: Staying
poems.author: Pierluigi Cappello

poems.poem:
I keep to myself what it means to tend a fire,
 the thick scent of soaked wood, a match between my fingers,
 the way a day resides in what’s to do, in another light
 split by the clouds, a different sunset tied to the tallest trees
 flush in the eyes of houses, on the poor man’s livestock;
 a touch here, a touch there — the way loneliness comes,
 today, a day like this, one day more alone.
   Translated from the Italian
poems.title: Staying
poems.author: Pierluigi Cappello

poems.poem:
The 3-D printer
 worked overtime
 sculpting lemon trees
poems.title: Techno-Origami
poems.author: Haji Khavari

poems.poem:
complete with bees
 on budding flowers.
 The overheated machine
 filled the cardboard orchard
 with the scent of hot plastic.
 The 12th nightingale arrived
 like a prophet
 in a cloud of smoke,
poems.title: Techno-Origami
poems.author: Haji Khavari

poems.poem:
considering the same hand
 that pushed “print”
 remained destined to strike
 a single match
 and wave goodbye
 to a paradise
 of paper.
   Translated from the Persian
poems.title: Techno-Origami
poems.author: Haji Khavari

poems.poem:
It’s not so easy to smash the compass.
 To rely on the winds     the golden hum of
 Herb Kane clouds navigating
 the tips of these mountains.
poems.title: Wākea’s Blue Teeth (a super bowl poem)
poems.author: Donovan Kūhiō Colleps

poems.poem:
It’s not so easy to modify the compass.
 To apologize when your brothers
 are spreading the sashimi
 and churning the shoyu mustard.
 
 It’s not so easy to ignore the compass
 because it seems to have always been here
poems.title: Wākea’s Blue Teeth (a super bowl poem)
poems.author: Donovan Kūhiō Colleps

poems.poem:
in all its sextant glory     pointing
 distracting you from Wākea’s blue teeth nibbling Papa’s chest.
 
 It’s not so easy     but it’s possible
 to say “aloha, for now” to family and friends
 pouring bags of ice into clean coolers
 before the big show.
poems.title: Wākea’s Blue Teeth (a super bowl poem)
poems.author: Donovan Kūhiō Colleps

poems.poem:
To walk past uncle’s squid lū‘au bubbling green,
 to get in that car and drive, with nothing
 but a fistful of quarters
 for the library Xerox machine.
 
 It’s possible     because when those books
 slide across the counter and you walk
 to an empty table     the compass begins to shake
poems.title: Wākea’s Blue Teeth (a super bowl poem)
poems.author: Donovan Kūhiō Colleps

poems.poem:
and the needle is never the same    again.
 
 With every turn of a Pacific page
 you realize      pukas are being filled
 or new ones      uncovered.
 And the art of listening brings with it memories,
 of the physics of his hips and hands     when you first saw him
 cast that net     slicing the horizon.
poems.title: Wākea’s Blue Teeth (a super bowl poem)
poems.author: Donovan Kūhiō Colleps

poems.poem:
The needle doesn’t like it when you flatten the cube
 to discover your kūpuna were always
 just around the corner    from where you sit      now.
 And the halftime show hasn’t even started, yet.
 
 The time it takes to get from the third million-dollar commercial
 to the fifth     is equal to the time it takes to find the Kānaka Maoli name
poems.title: Wākea’s Blue Teeth (a super bowl poem)
poems.author: Donovan Kūhiō Colleps

poems.poem:
of the land that raised you     buried under the pavements     under
 the brand new      two-lane     fast food      drive-thru.
 
 But what the compass really hates      what it’s really afraid of
 is when you see the lo‘i in the same way that you see
 that empty Sunday afternoon library     when you finally
 see the moana in your kūpuna’s eye.
poems.title: Wākea’s Blue Teeth (a super bowl poem)
poems.author: Donovan Kūhiō Colleps

poems.poem:
So now      when you return home and the cooler is empty
 and the sashimi spiral is nearly gone   unfurl
 those Xerox copies across the dining table     consoling
 the cousins who lost money on the spread.
 
 And as the compass repairs itself    as it always does
 it will feel the sting when it finds you       tomorrow
 with your back being warmed by the morning sun.
poems.title: Wākea’s Blue Teeth (a super bowl poem)
poems.author: Donovan Kūhiō Colleps

poems.poem:
How does beginning go how does
 remembering without forgetting go
 in front of me in the snow a man
 his back lonesome somber
 how does beginning go not remembering
 flashes of light that showed him images when he
poems.title: We Are Alive. We Are for Everything
poems.author: Daniela Danz

poems.poem:
was a boy quick and blinding see the shadows
 in the light how does not-remembering go
 listen to the hissing see the light
 and Germany’s lightness
 how bright Germany is like soot
 like images quick and blinding how does
 beginning go smell the snow
 it’s new it fell in the night
poems.title: We Are Alive. We Are for Everything
poems.author: Daniela Danz

poems.poem:
in the dark gets forgotten
 in images quick listen to the snow
 it lies light like linen
 something’s burning a hissing somber
 like images at night on walls listen
 to the hissing smell the smell of burning
 look at the soot on a white background
   Translated from the German
poems.title: We Are Alive. We Are for Everything
poems.author: Daniela Danz

poems.poem:
From a ways, the sky and your hands
 come to my eyes, from some distant part of you;
 it’s snowing out, you’re all in the white of the snow
 every track in the candor a wound
 and the field beyond the window is a body
poems.title: White
poems.author: Pierluigi Cappello

poems.poem:
a glance that becomes a pronouncement,
 the heat of breath, your head adrift in sleeplessness;
 
 that’s where it returns, in a word translated into silence
 where the sparrows tie loose knots
 your palms on your eyes, chest on your knees
 forehead in the snow.
   Translated from the Italian
poems.title: White
poems.author: Pierluigi Cappello

poems.poem:
Old and blind and in love
 with light, he’d reach for
 the hands of writers to guide
 him back to the landscape,
 once the subject of his photo-
 graphs. Often he’d see just
 how hard it was to render it
 right, and would feel free
 of such burdens. A last cloud
 on a lake he’d let carry him
poems.title: Apertures
poems.author: Howard Altmann

poems.poem:
into night. Breaking sounds
 of autumn he’d leave a pond
 to compose, rustling the stream
 of images. The panicked flight
 of the hunted he’d let the dry
 grasses capture, their golden
 yield his release. Even in
 the crimson cusp of an evening
poems.title: Apertures
poems.author: Howard Altmann

poems.poem:
he’d wedge himself, curling
 into a ball without twilight
 ever sinking him. The man
 swam with the fog and its
 very touch of resolve. Further
 than any writer his shadows
 lapped up the sand. All this
 in the ebb and flow of a ninth
poems.title: Apertures
poems.author: Howard Altmann

poems.poem:
decade by the tide, an inlet
 mapped by its egress to the sky.
 And when moonlight would
 come to wash his window,
 a heavy tome floating lost
 worlds on his lap, often
 his other hand would read
 the apertures of old cameras,
poems.title: Apertures
poems.author: Howard Altmann

poems.poem:
an author’s intent the subject
 of his alignments. But when
 the milky skies would dip
 the hand of a writer in
 the milky seas, to the light-
 house he’d ascend, dreaming
 of being a writer who was
 blind, tracing a horizon.
poems.title: Apertures
poems.author: Howard Altmann

poems.poem:
I like when the form is kind of stuck-up
    even though I’ve got a Southern accent and my place
 looks like a graduate student’s. 1. I enjoy
    high art but realism swamps me.
poems.title: The Aristocracy
poems.author: Sandra Simonds

poems.poem:
2. The material world swamps me.
                               3. I came to understand
                                                 the forms of realism,
                                                              the aesthetic phenomenon.
                                                                       4. You take a random person
                                                                                                 from daily life.
                                                                    5. You take their dependence
                                                          on their historical circumstances.
poems.title: The Aristocracy
poems.author: Sandra Simonds

poems.poem:
6. You make them
                                                          the subject.
                                       7. You see, they operate
                                       the modern.
       Things happen ... minutes, hours, days.
        The order of life
           coming from life itself.
                                      Back to life /
poems.title: The Aristocracy
poems.author: Sandra Simonds

poems.poem:
Back to reality (like Soul II Soul).
                                                        It is sublime
                                                    and grotesque.
                                                                 8. They make rich forms.
    Something steady.
    Less manic.
          Something real
                                                 like a bell
poems.title: The Aristocracy
poems.author: Sandra Simonds

poems.poem:
inside the Golden Seahorse Gift Shop.
 
                                                                 Don’t take me
                                                                             on that ride.
                                                             I don’t want
                                                          to go down.
 
                                          9. To what degree
poems.title: The Aristocracy
poems.author: Sandra Simonds

poems.poem:
are the subjects
          taken seriously?
    They naturally swim
                             beneath the icy sheets
                                                and find breathing holes.
                                          They may remember
                                                          their arctic homes.
                                                                             They are one of the park’s
poems.title: The Aristocracy
poems.author: Sandra Simonds

poems.poem:
most sociable creatures. I said
                                           enter the water with them.
                                Graceful imitation of strange
    palms and seaflowers. A seaflower
      of a thousand colors, aquarium
               pigmented. It is my violent
   passion for seaflowers, Molly.
 I want the entire
poems.title: The Aristocracy
poems.author: Sandra Simonds

poems.poem:
underwater palace
           built of roaring seaflowers!
     Beluga! Beluga! Wither and mow.
          The child’s song.
 
   Emerald kayak
         and the femme fatale
                                  who sleeps in it, Victorian,
poems.title: The Aristocracy
poems.author: Sandra Simonds

poems.poem:
long, frothy hair
                                          and the death drive,
      flesh like the statement, “I lost a friend
           in the sea garden.”
                           The notes, staccato, vortex,
                                            paradisiacal, gold bell in a coffin
      just in case I wake up. And the way
                                                  darkness tunnels
poems.title: The Aristocracy
poems.author: Sandra Simonds

poems.poem:
inside a car on its way
                         to its pinpoint destination.
 No one tells you
                     the moon’s going
                                              to end up like this.
                                          No one. So you just move towards it.
     That’s all the moon
                                ever was. Ding. Ding.
poems.title: The Aristocracy
poems.author: Sandra Simonds

poems.poem:
If not being (something)
 is the same as being,
 
 then I will live forever.
   •
poems.title: Bees
poems.author: Rae Armantrout

poems.poem:
Round shadow inside
 the sunflower’s
 
 corona.
   • 
 
 If I lived forever
 would the present’s noose
poems.title: Bees
poems.author: Rae Armantrout

poems.poem:
be looser?
   • 
 
 Moon shadow
 made of angry bees,
 
 confined. Come in.
poems.title: Bees
poems.author: Rae Armantrout

poems.poem:
This is what happened
 the dead were settling in under their mud roof
 and something was shuffling overhead
poems.title: Body
poems.author: Alice Oswald

poems.poem:
it was a badger treading on the thin partition
 
 bewildered were the dead
 going about their days and nights in the dark
 putting their feet down carefully and finding themselves floating
 but that badger
 
 still with the simple heavy box of his body needing to be lifted
poems.title: Body
poems.author: Alice Oswald

poems.poem:
was shuffling away alive
 
 hard at work
 with the living shovel of himself
 into the lane he dropped
          not once looking up
 
 and missed the sight of his own corpse falling like a suitcase towards him
poems.title: Body
poems.author: Alice Oswald

poems.poem:
with the grin like an opened zip
          (as I found it this morning)
 
 and went on running with that bindweed will of his
 went on running along the hedge and into the earth again
 trembling
 as if in a broken jug for one backwards moment
                water might keep its shape
poems.title: Body
poems.author: Alice Oswald

poems.poem:
The bug’s psalm: don’t get crushed.
 Afterlives feel meaningless
 but spring will come,
 push out the nubs
 the kids braid into pallets.
 Take up your pallet
 from lawns noon’s hardly touched.
 The small think gods
 just loll on clouds.
 Bugs think gods just crush.
poems.title: bug’s psalm
poems.author: Rodney Koeneke

poems.poem:
If we were in infinity, we would be everywhere,
 even inside ourselves, as taste resides in the walnut,
 and the walnut resides in the shell.
 Then we would thrive inside the subjunctive,
 where nothing happens but dreams of being,
 as paradise dreams of its inferno,
 the inferno of cotton candy.
 If only the world had ripened, like a pear,
 it might have melted the mirror in me,
 delivering its softness to the hard road of the mind,
poems.title: Darkness of the Subjunctive
poems.author: Paul Hoover

poems.poem:
sixty miles from town.
               And if our grammar were even to our heat,
 comma, conditional phrase, comma,
 we’d be addicted to the sentence,
 sentenced to an exile that sees, hears, and thinks,
 and is often mistaken for love.
               Trees are chronologies;
 every leaf shines, and in turning over it winks an eye:
poems.title: Darkness of the Subjunctive
poems.author: Paul Hoover

poems.poem:
if, if, and then. The world is possible meaning;
 the world is possible, meaning:
 I might have been an elf, had I been elfin.
 But I am not an elf. I am a giant with tiny hands:
 would, could, and should.
 Had I been winged, I might have flown
 from industrial field to pastoral alley
 on great woolen wings, with the blue face of a bee.
poems.title: Darkness of the Subjunctive
poems.author: Paul Hoover

poems.poem:
Then it would have been said, “He is repairing to his persona,”
 or “He is retiring to his future.”
 I’ll copy this by way of the stars, reflective.
 Get back to me by facsimile or dream of climbing a night ladder
 to the place of ideal size, near a town of simple affection.
 If we had been born, lived our lives, and died,
 we might have existed. On the side of darkness, infinity;
 on the other, a sixty watt bulb.
poems.title: Darkness of the Subjunctive
poems.author: Paul Hoover

poems.poem:
This is the day the flies fall awake mid-sentence
 and lie stunned on the windowsill shaking with speeches
 only it isn’t speech it is trembling sections of puzzlement which
 break off suddenly as if the questioner had been shot
 
 this is one of those wordy days
 when they drop from their winter quarters in the curtains and sizzle as they fall
 feeling like old cigarette butts called back to life
poems.title: Flies
poems.author: Alice Oswald

poems.poem:
blown from the surface of some charred world
 
 and somehow their wings which are little more than flakes of dead skin
 have carried them to this blackened disembodied question
 
 what dirt shall we visit today?
 what dirt shall we re-visit?
poems.title: Flies
poems.author: Alice Oswald

poems.poem:
they lift their faces to the past and walk about a bit
 trying out their broken thought-machines
 coming back with their used-up words
 
 there is such a horrible trapped buzzing wherever we fly
 it’s going to be impossible to think clearly now until next winter
 what should we
 what dirt should we
poems.title: Flies
poems.author: Alice Oswald

poems.poem:
i came close to his WET dog’s eye & a FAT tear shared animal PAIN sloshed & seeped in between us — “darling I’m sorry you were born a dog & people notice it” , 
 
 2 COME ON IN, WE’VE BEEN EXPECTING YOU
 
 like a clue
poems.title: From “more flinching”
poems.author: Heather Phillipson

poems.poem:
we found PEOPLE
 in the KITCHEN
 in the SUICIDE VEST
 with the KALASHNIKOV
 
 such beautiful, desperate weapons
 their faces
poems.title: From “more flinching”
poems.author: Heather Phillipson

poems.poem:
had to be covered
 so we didn’t fall in love
 piteously
 with the self-same wretchedness
 we see in mirrors
 
 a worryingly familiar scene
 we’ve lived in will live in
poems.title: From “more flinching”
poems.author: Heather Phillipson

poems.poem:
the carnage
 going on
 behind closed doors
 
 being told, regurgitatingly, “you only get one shot!”
 
 but is it true
 you only get one shot
poems.title: From “more flinching”
poems.author: Heather Phillipson

poems.poem:
when you get a loaded magazine
 & plenty more
 where that came from
 in the MUNITIONS DEPOT
 which I picture in Arizona, right
 beside a render farm
 and to the left
 THE CLOUD
poems.title: From “more flinching”
poems.author: Heather Phillipson

poems.poem:
that backs up
 and up and up
 up
 to where
 are there edges, Bobby?
 
 INTELLIGENCE tells us
 to test the power of names
poems.title: From “more flinching”
poems.author: Heather Phillipson

poems.poem:
by naming things, for one thing
 to name is to guarantee the end
 like a starting pistol
 BANG
 
 
             you name
                             it         it’s
poems.title: From “more flinching”
poems.author: Heather Phillipson

poems.poem:
!
 
 
                  smithereens
poems.title: From “more flinching”
poems.author: Heather Phillipson

poems.poem:
4
 
 I am so indifferent
 to the limits
 of feelings
 I can’t tell the difference
poems.title: From “more flinching”
poems.author: Heather Phillipson

poems.poem:
every time someone lifts my flap
 the unwashed salad
 the unheated leftovers
 the sanitary products are standard
 but bear no relation
 to what I expected
 to feel overlaid
 with various forms of filth
poems.title: From “more flinching”
poems.author: Heather Phillipson

poems.poem:
don’t you sometimes feel
 like getting wrapped in a dog towel
 and buried in the hardening ground
 under the Canadian maple? Do dogs
 need to approach death
 and back away from it
 like I did when the vet injected
 deep pentobarbital & his bowels
poems.title: From “more flinching”
poems.author: Heather Phillipson

poems.poem:
ejected across the floor tiles
 I was there
 to inhale his fur and weep
 for my benefit
 I am not independent
 of my feelings this way
 of talking about feelings
 has fooled each one of us
poems.title: From “more flinching”
poems.author: Heather Phillipson

poems.poem:
I’d rather be given CBT
                              by a border collie
 when there are fewer words around
 my arms around
 his only
 adored and stinking
 neck 
 dead
poems.title: From “more flinching”
poems.author: Heather Phillipson

poems.poem: up my nostrils throw me in there with him everything is in the cold awful and I’m not OK and without good reason still here and
poems.title: From “more flinching”
poems.author: Heather Phillipson

poems.poem:
feelings  
  
  
 
 6 JUST A GENTLE REMINDER
 
 A LOT OF WORK
poems.title: From “more flinching”
poems.author: Heather Phillipson

poems.poem:
goes into making sex alluring sex
 is just this and that
 but it seemed, for a moment, that a new
 climax had been won when
 even the sky fingered me
 with a slobbery insistence when
 we were retching with so much desire
 we created a whole new atmosphere
poems.title: From “more flinching”
poems.author: Heather Phillipson

poems.poem:
grabbing at sex things /
 using the sick bag to be actually sick in
 now the shower curtain is transparent
 it’s a way of saying, “I want you too
 to have this experience
 so that we are more alike
 like a sign that life struck once
 in a slippy-bits marathon
poems.title: From “more flinching”
poems.author: Heather Phillipson

poems.poem:
that began when our eyes were magnets
 yanked to each other’s fully-charged
 crotches at a picnic
 when it was essential
 to make every enhancement
 to our ‘connection’ by getting seriously indecent
 beside the Bluetooth wireless speaker system
 until even the trees had to dash inside
poems.title: From “more flinching”
poems.author: Heather Phillipson

poems.poem:
to pour ice in their underpants”
 while I choked up playing the scene, as we lived it,
 united by our pursuit of arrhythmia or
 satisfying itches to that
 catchy bridge section in Chopin
 (I couldn’t wait to come
 with Chopin through his melancholic meadow
 (not that I approve of background music
poems.title: From “more flinching”
poems.author: Heather Phillipson

poems.poem:
(I prefer to foreground the piano
 by massaging it loud and all over
 until the top layer comes off in my hand
 and the pedal squeaks for humanity
 (I like to FEEL a piano as an instrument
 of interruption and consciousness
 (though I also like to take light swims, to get away
 from what I FEEL (today I felt
poems.title: From “more flinching”
poems.author: Heather Phillipson

poems.poem:
jelly beans resemble kidneys))))))
 which throbs like everyone grieving
  
    
  
  
 7 HERE, HAVE A NEW PUPPY
poems.title: From “more flinching”
poems.author: Heather Phillipson

poems.poem:
said the Russians to the French
 to soften the dog-loss
 but mostly the dog’s image the image
 is the greater likeness
 except we never seem to run out of images
 sometimes something in an image
 runs through me and that is very common
 as is reading about something
poems.title: From “more flinching”
poems.author: Heather Phillipson

poems.poem:
that’s happening to someone outside of me
 until I know someone outside of me
 without any knowledge
 it is a test for my knowledge
 to hang around until morning
 practically all mornings are news to me
 practically all knowledge is news to me
 practically all news is images
poems.title: From “more flinching”
poems.author: Heather Phillipson

poems.poem:
going very fast around the world
 so we have to guzzle them
 like wrapped food
 — hot and on the run —
 in one end and squitted out the other
 [pics or it didn’t happen]
 until I’m fat with implications
 and containing not a sausage
poems.title: From “more flinching”
poems.author: Heather Phillipson

poems.poem:
9
 
 I love a good weepy
 dog-meme as much as the next crybaby
 and nauseate irregularly
 when the gifs load automatically
poems.title: From “more flinching”
poems.author: Heather Phillipson

poems.poem:
his hairy body
 into my hairy body
 
 unfairly the dog
 becomes the shape of 2:13 p.m.
 in me on a Tuesday
 
 if we accept the world as totally fucked
poems.title: From “more flinching”
poems.author: Heather Phillipson

poems.poem:
there’s a lot worse coming
 than dog hairs in macaroni cheese dog hairs on pillows dog hairs in rented flats in bathtubs in my hair in my dog’s hair in your short & curlies between my teeth in coagulant soap bars
 
 some people are revolted
 by dogs and dogs
 are not up for revolting
 I am revolted
 when dogs are lacking
poems.title: From “more flinching”
poems.author: Heather Phillipson

poems.poem:
what if he did lick my cheeks
 by which I mean “buttocks”
 which were coated in whipped shea butter and
 heavily comestible
 
 it’s obvious he’s related to a father
 he never knew
poems.title: From “more flinching”
poems.author: Heather Phillipson

poems.poem:
because we found all his needs
 and perverted them
 into a kind of inter-species loyalty
 or the usual master-slave hierarchy
 
 before laying down the crisp breakfast bowl
 of the rest of his days
 which gave us carte blanche to rush in anytime
poems.title: From “more flinching”
poems.author: Heather Phillipson

poems.poem:
and smother him with kisses
 without getting socked in the eye
 (unlike when I tried the same on Johnny (who spat my tongue out
       (& no one blamed him)))
 when maybe all he wants is
 just to go on
 being less and less
 subtle and alive
poems.title: From “more flinching”
poems.author: Heather Phillipson

poems.poem:
the way life becomes
 very well known after its termination
  
  
 12
 If rigor mortis sets in
 it means there’s somebody who needs it.
 It means that somebody
poems.title: From “more flinching”
poems.author: Heather Phillipson

poems.poem:
is drained and not awake
 and deems any speckles of life unusable
 and he is dead and dead
 all dead in the humus
 of trashed bodies shoved down there
 dressed in made-up relationships.
 
 What’s your favorite part?
poems.title: From “more flinching”
poems.author: Heather Phillipson

poems.poem:
Mine’s every part
 with a maggot in it. Maggots
 mean that life’s still leaking.
 
 It’s like magic
 when his dead voice
 is nauseating
 and I can’t see him
poems.title: From “more flinching”
poems.author: Heather Phillipson

poems.poem:
so he might as well be invisible.
 It’s like magic when he isn’t
 and doesn’t have anything to say
 and I can’t bear to listen anyway
 so I just recognize my fingers / all
 the injuries they’ve inflicted
 while my skin drops off.
poems.title: From “more flinching”
poems.author: Heather Phillipson

poems.poem:
What’s worse than a maggot
 in the EAT ME
 GLOVE-BOX DATES?
 Does the 5-second rule apply
 to something that drops dead?
 Is it true he might come back
 and crack open a piñata
 blue alcopops, bombay mix, karaoke, and a pint of nostalgia
poems.title: From “more flinching”
poems.author: Heather Phillipson

poems.poem:
which is like thinking in another language,
 I mean, how it feels, not what it means.
 
 Half a maggot, the memory of
 mange marching across his fur
 describes a lot of other feelings
 the feeling that someone else is taking up the whole room
 the feeling that no one could help me now
poems.title: From “more flinching”
poems.author: Heather Phillipson

poems.poem:
or ever whether I was on several edges
 my hot core and noggin facing this hammering world
 of brainlessness and sweetbreads
 was always a favorite word.
 I don’t know what it tastes like but I know it’s terrible.
 
 a:ldskjfa:lkdgjsa
 meaning
poems.title: From “more flinching”
poems.author: Heather Phillipson

poems.poem:
I’m so overcharged
 that all I can do is literally slam
 my hands / head / breasts against the keyboard.
 
 Wherever there are
 corpses there are maggots.
 If we dig him up will he be wearing a jacket?
 LOOK OUT
poems.title: From “more flinching”
poems.author: Heather Phillipson

poems.poem:
for the milkier, gentler solaces
 which for all we know                   for all we know
 could be the wind
 or Chopin’s noise (still hammering the background) —
 who’s seen it? Only its aftermath
 is visible what’s not visible
 is the aftermath of my screaming
poems.title: From “more flinching”
poems.author: Heather Phillipson

poems.poem:
20
 
 you can catch me on the
 
      FLOOR / DOG / SYRINGE
 
 periphery of the dying
poems.title: From “more flinching”
poems.author: Heather Phillipson

poems.poem:
and dead scene
 
      FACE (FEMALE)
 
 maybe my whole life
 carting sensations to the center
 mopping shit up with towels
poems.title: From “more flinching”
poems.author: Heather Phillipson

poems.poem:
SKULL / COFFIN
 
 (there are feelings for these things)
 while public petting
 
      CAR / PLANE / ROCKET
 
 bodies leak it’s no surprise what I give away
poems.title: From “more flinching”
poems.author: Heather Phillipson

poems.poem:
ONE DROPLET
 
 you can have when the vet twirls off to deal
 with some bloody business in a kitchen
 
      KNIFE / GUN
poems.title: From “more flinching”
poems.author: Heather Phillipson

poems.poem:
the hug-a-corpse scene gets deep in
 the hold of what I am
 
      PARTY POPPER / WASTEBIN
 
 is what I’ve not yet been
poems.title: From “more flinching”
poems.author: Heather Phillipson

poems.poem:
30
 
 Who concocts the smell
 of dogs which smells like
 an extreme close-up
 of the world oozing
 in at the edges.
 Full as an ice cube is full of liquid.
poems.title: From “more flinching”
poems.author: Heather Phillipson

poems.poem:
I mistook it for solidity.
 
 The world is too full of smells.
 Though it’s impossible
 to see the top of it
 they crawl between my legs
 in the shimmering fuzz
 on top of the plant
poems.title: From “more flinching”
poems.author: Heather Phillipson

poems.poem:
stickers of evenings
 tongues held out
 pocket-friendly air fresheners
 strikes on our nostrils.
 They come at me streaming.
 
 Why the dog? Why not
 the dog? Was it only a dream
poems.title: From “more flinching”
poems.author: Heather Phillipson

poems.poem:
of soil heating held
 and stimulated
 for his unique aroma.
 It’s not a way in
 but it places you somewhere
 that smells strong
 and looks strong leaving
 behind us. Hi.
poems.title: From “more flinching”
poems.author: Heather Phillipson

poems.poem:
while he lives
 
 here’s a list
 
 of images
 
 light in a filthy glass
poems.title: Hematology
poems.author: sam sax

poems.poem:
pigeon dead on the high spiked window
 
 clear plastic bag above him full of water if water could kill everything that lives in you & it can — 
 
 i sit in a corner of the cancer ward
 
 fingering the app that shows me
poems.title: Hematology
poems.author: sam sax

poems.poem:
other faggots in this hospital
 
 chat with one
 
 i might meet in radiology
 
 but don’t       instead
poems.title: Hematology
poems.author: sam sax

poems.poem:
make the sick man laugh
 
 while he’s conscious
 
 compliment his gown
 
 his new brutal cheekbones
poems.title: Hematology
poems.author: sam sax

poems.poem:
that appeared with the chemo
 
 if only it were simple as a magnet
 
 sucking the bad metals out of him
 
 if only i could make a better list
poems.title: Hematology
poems.author: sam sax

poems.poem:
more magic      less language
 
 periphrastic & restorative
 
 if only i met that stranger
 
 in the basement
poems.title: Hematology
poems.author: sam sax

poems.poem:
& our pleasure rose
 
 through the hospital
 
 bliss poultice
 
 for the sorrow-skinned who sit
poems.title: Hematology
poems.author: sam sax

poems.poem:
half-conscious & half-machinery
 
 while the sick man lives
 
 all i can do is recount
 
 the vast pastoral of his illness
poems.title: Hematology
poems.author: sam sax

poems.poem:
when he is gone i’m counting
 
 on all the good flooding back
 
 his beard
 
 a collapsed country
poems.title: Hematology
poems.author: sam sax

poems.poem:
i’ll refuge inside
 
 his laugh
 
 a memory
 
 so liquid
poems.title: Hematology
poems.author: sam sax

poems.poem:
i’ll hear it
 
 when anyone
 
 opens a window
 
 to scare the birds
poems.title: Hematology
poems.author: sam sax

poems.poem:
Doesn’t that shining line
 Of ocean, broken
 Suggest a ship at sea,
 Or something? Ah, if to be
 “At sea” is to be lost,
poems.title: Le Séducteur
poems.author: Laura Mullen

poems.poem:
Left out, or just un-
 Certain of the meaning,
 Someone else chimes in.
 Nevermind, I’m sure it’s
 Nothing, someone else insists
 Of this impossible vessel — 
 Crafted of affect and lack
 Of glasses, the sail a conceit
poems.title: Le Séducteur
poems.author: Laura Mullen

poems.poem:
Of low clouds, the bow
 A row of breakers, sun
 Glinting off the port-
 Hole (imagined) of the cabin
 Below whose bed is also,
 As we say, the sea-
 Bed or floor (as if it were
 A dwelling down there,
poems.title: Le Séducteur
poems.author: Laura Mullen

poems.poem:
Where the restless sleepers
 Are scattered bone). A ship
 At sea is only a figure
 Of speech somebody else
 Claims: a quick shape — 
 Suggested by the passage
 Of a cloud and the tug
 Of  the current; a thin dream
poems.title: Le Séducteur
poems.author: Laura Mullen

poems.poem:
Already almost forgotten ... 
 If you can forget the cargo,
 Another adds, which was
 Human: though that fact
 Was somehow less visible
 To the traders than the trade
 Routes traced out across
 The dissolving paper
poems.title: Le Séducteur
poems.author: Laura Mullen

poems.poem:
Map, under a spill of silver
 Coins poured out. Life
 Is brief, one might sigh
 At this point: a matter
 Of water in water
 Moving, each of us
 Carefully bearing
 The bags we packed
poems.title: Le Séducteur
poems.author: Laura Mullen

poems.poem:
With cherished flotsam
 And jetsam, clutching
 A one-way ticket
 Printed on a spume
 Of wind-blown white ...  
 A pretty image, used
 To excuse too much:
 As if the lives enslaved
poems.title: Le Séducteur
poems.author: Laura Mullen

poems.poem:
Were worthless as this
 Sudden welling up
 Of what is mostly self-
 Pity (salt at my lips,
 You say, my vision
 Swimming). Nothing.
 It’s nothing but ... 
 It’s nothing. To be
poems.title: Le Séducteur
poems.author: Laura Mullen

poems.poem:
At sea is also to be,
 As we say, astray or
 In the dark, hoping
 For terra firma, and
 To be enlightened,
 Soon, as to just what
 Was meant by that sad
 Laugh and last remark.
poems.title: Le Séducteur
poems.author: Laura Mullen
